conversation.content: [shocked] You can't tear this down, this greenhouse has been here since 1952! [shaky voice] My grandmother built it with her own hands after the war, every pane of glass has a story.
Look, I've got a work order signed by the property owner, demolition starts in two hours. The structure's been condemned for safety violations, asbestos in the frame joints.

[frustrated] The property owner is my uncle who hasn't set foot here in twenty years! [loudly] He doesn't understand that this place holds the last remaining specimens of three extinct orchid varieties.
[dismissive] Extinct orchids don't pay property taxes, and sentiment doesn't fix structural damage. [sighs] I've been doing this for fifteen years, buildings come down, life moves on.
[desperate] Please, just give me forty-eight hours to relocate the plants. [very quietly] Some of these specimens are over seventy years old, they're irreplaceable genetic material.
[firmly] Not happening.
You don't understand what you're destroying here! This isn't just glass and metal, it's a living laboratory that's contributed to three Nobel Prize-winning studies.
Nobel Prizes don't change the fact that the roof could collapse any minute. My insurance won't cover delays for plant rescue missions, especially not two-day ones.
What if I pay you directly? [speeding up] Double your fee to wait, I'll sign a liability waiver, take full responsibility for any accidents or delays that occur.
[bitter] Money won't bring back the contracts I'll lose if I don't stay on schedule. [pause] The city's watching this job, one delay and they'll pull my license.
[crying while speaking] Fine then.
[monotone] Look, I can give you ninety minutes to grab what you can carry. [quietly] That's already risking my crew's overtime and pushing our next site visit.
[angry] Ninety minutes to save forty years of research? [laughs bitterly] You might as well hand me a teaspoon and tell me to empty the ocean.
[frustrated] It's ninety minutes or nothing, and the clock starts now whether you take it or not. [exhales] My crew's already unloading the equipment.
[furious] Your crew can unload all they want, but I'm calling the historical society right now. [shaky voice] This greenhouse is eligible for heritage protection, you'll need court approval.
[condescending] Heritage protection requires a sixty-day filing period, which I'm guessing you didn't know about. [slowly] The demolition permit supersedes any application filed after issuance.
[defeated] So that's it then, you're just going to destroy everything because some paperwork says you can? [very quietly] My grandmother's ghost will haunt this empty lot.
[tired] Ghosts don't bother me anymore, I've demolished three churches, two theaters, and a children's hospital. [sighs] Your greenhouse won't even make my top ten regrets.
[bitter] I hope when they tear down something you love, the destroyer is exactly as heartless as you're being right now.
Everything I loved was already torn down years ago. [very quietly] That's how I ended up in this business, might as well be the one holding the sledgehammer. [pause] Eighty-five minutes left.

scenario: A botanist returns to her childhood home to find a demolition expert preparing to destroy the historic greenhouse where her late grandmother taught her everything about plants.
